value.title: Daily Crunch: IBM is getting out of facial recognition
value.excerpt: IBM’s CEO takes a stand on mass surveillance, Apple may soon make a big chip announcement and Google Maps gets new features to help users navigate transit safely. Here’s your Daily Crunch for . 1. IBM ends all facial recognition business as CEO calls out bias and inequality

images.title: Daily Crunch: IBM is getting out of facial recognition

value.title: IBM won’t develop facial recognition tech for mass surveillance anymore
value.excerpt: IBM said yesterday that it won’t offer or develop general-purpose facial recognition technology to encourage responsible usage of tech by law enforcement. The company has been a big player in the field for years offering several solutions.

images.title: IBM won’t develop facial recognition tech for mass surveillance anymore

value.title: IBM stops work on facial recognition over human rights concerns
value.excerpt: IBM is exiting its facial recognition business over concerns of possible human rights violations and racial biases.

images.title: IBM stops work on facial recognition over human rights concerns

value.title: Senator fears Clearview AI facial recognition could be used on protesters
value.excerpt: Sen. Edward Markey asks if the company considers a history of discriminatory policing before selling the tech to certain law enforcement agencies.

value.title: Balancing Privacy Concerns Around Facial Recognition

value.title: ACLU sues Clearview AI over 'unlawful' facial recognition technology
value.excerpt: Facial recognition software provider Clearview AI has been hit with a lawsuit by the American Civil Liberties Union and several other organizations. The lawsuit, filed in state court in Illinois, accuses the firm of violating state privacy laws over its use of facial recognition and biometric technology.

value.title: Computer vision and uncertainty in AI for robotic prosthetics
value.excerpt: Researchers have developed new software that can be integrated with existing hardware to enable people using robotic prosthetics or exoskeletons to walk in a safer, more natural manner on different types of terrain.

value.title: New models use computer vision and AI to identify COVID-19 in X-rays
value.excerpt: Students at Cranfield University have designed computer models that can identify COVID-19 in X-rays. The models use computer vision and artificial intelligence (AI) to analyze chest X-ray imagery. It can classify information which would not normally be recognized with the naked eye and assist with the diagnosis of COVID-19.

images.title: New models use computer vision and AI to identify COVID-19 in X-rays

value.title: U.S. Blacklists Dozens of Chinese Companies Working on AI, Face Recognition Tech
value.excerpt: The U.S. Commerce Department has put another 33 Chinese businesses—many of which develop artificial intelligence and face recognition tech—on its economic blacklist as a punitive measure for purportedly conspiring with Beijing and the government’s brutal crackdown on Muslim minorities.
